Title.evidence: The EMPATHY Study: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio

Participants.evidence: Eligible patients had elevated low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) and diabetic retinopathy.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to receive either intensive or standard statin therapy.

Objective.evidence: The EMPATHY study investigates whether intensive statin therapy is more effective than standard therapy in reducing cardiovascular events in patients with hyperlipidemia and diabetic retinopathy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was a composite of CVD incidence and CVD-related death, measured over a maximum follow-up period of 5.5 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment ensured.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to treatment allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 5,144 patients were randomised, with 2,571 assigned to intensive therapy and 2,573 to standard therapy.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Baseline data were analysed for 5,107 patients (2,550 in the intensive therapy group and 2,557 in the standard therapy group) using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The effect size and precision of the primary outcome are detailed in the full manuscript.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were monitored, with no significant differences reported between groups.

Funding.evidence: Funding sources are disclosed in the full manuscript.
